ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned some common components of embedded systems.
I developed the skills to design and build my own projects, using so many different features like wifi, sensors, and interactivity.
Loads. Lots of how to work with raspberry pis, work with motors and sensors. How to actually apply CS department into building things.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was a class that let me create a lot of cool stuff but the structure of the class made every other week a lot of work.

The strengths are definitely the projects and how small the course is. There is so much room for students to really grow and learn on their own through projects, and the course is designed to create a tight knit cohort of students who are all ~suffering~ through the course together. Weaknesses: The course is very high workload, and a lot of it is learning on your own (I didn't find the lecture part of the course very helpful). It's definitely a grind :(

Scott is amazing. Knows his stuff, cares, and is funny. Class is all just projects. Thats it. So if you don't like projects don't take it. The group project near the end felt too big and then it felt like the final project was rushed. But maybe just easing off the gas a bit and better pacing. Outside of that its great.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to other students who like to make things but also like coding, they would also need to have a lot of spare time in their schedule because this class is a lot of work.

Absolutely! This course is SO much fun, and as a CS major, I genuinely learned so much from this course, especially when it comes to applying my CS skills to something physical I can hold in my hands. I think this is a class that every CS major should take, and I'm so glad I took it, even though it was very difficult and high workload

Absolutely. Best CS class ive taken. Only if you actually want to apply yourself though, and previous work with some of Arduino or sensors or raspberry pis or some mechanical construction makes things much easier and will save you time (you obv dont need all of this though). For sure though if you want to get to build things. I'm not an art person at all, it wasn't too artys fartsy, but did engage you and make you think about what you were building. Graded generously from my experience, mostly cares about effort.
